# Design interactive grade 6 English course (2025-10-08 20:04Z)

_**User (2025-10-08 20:04Z)**_

I want you design an interactive course on English Language Arts covering Vocabulary, Grammar, Reading Comprehension, English Writing and the course to be at a level of Grade 6 of california curriculam.

The course will be accessible by web interface and should track progress and student should be able to navigate the course chapters.

+                 explanation: "There are several types of context clues:\n\n1. **Definition Clues**: The word is directly defined in the sentence.\n2. **Synonym Clues**: A similar word is used nearby.\n3. **Antonym Clues**: An opposite word gives you a hint.\n4. **Example Clues**: Examples help explain the word.\n5. **Inference Clues**: You use logic and prior knowledge.",
+                 examples: [
+                   {
+                     text: "The luminous stars shone brightly in the night sky.",

+                 explanation: "**Simple Sentences** contain one independent clause (one subject and one verb).\n- Example: The cat sleeps.\n- Example: Maria and Juan played basketball.\n\n**Compound Sentences** contain two or more independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction (FANBOYS: for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so).\n- Example: The cat sleeps, and the dog barks.\n- Example: I wanted to go to the park, but it started raining.\n\n**Key Rule**: Use a comma before the coordinating conjunction in a compound sentence.",

For all these reasons, students should aim to exercise at least 60 minutes every day.",

@@ -1,1 +1,104 @@
- 
+ // Progress Tracking Utility using Local Storage
+ 
+ const PROGRESS_KEY = 'english-tutor-progress';
+ 
+ export const progressTracker = {
+   // Initialize progress
+   initProgress() {
+     const existingProgress = this.getProgress();
+     if (!existingProgress) {
+       const initialProgress = {
+         completedLessons: [],
+         exerciseScores: {},
+         lastAccessed: null,
+         currentLesson: null
+       };
+       localStorage.setItem(PROGRESS_KEY, JSON.stringify(initialProgress));
+       return initialProgress;
+     }
+     return existingProgress;
+   },
+ 
+   // Get all progress
+   getProgress() {
+     const progress = localStorage.getItem(PROGRESS_KEY);
+     return progress ? JSON.parse(progress) : null;
+   },
+ 
+   // Mark a lesson as complete
+   completeLesson(lessonId) {
+     const progress = this.getProgress() || this.initProgress();
+     if (!progress.completedLessons.includes(lessonId)) {
+       progress.completedLessons.push(lessonId);
+       localStorage.setItem(PROGRESS_KEY, JSON.stringify(progress));
+     }
+   },
+ 
+   // Check if a lesson is completed
+   isLessonCompleted(lessonId) {
+     const progress = this.getProgress() || this.initProgress();
+     return progress.completedLessons.includes(lessonId);
+   },
+ 
+   // Save exercise score
+   saveExerciseScore(exerciseId, score, totalQuestions) {
+     const progress = this.getProgress() || this.initProgress();
+     progress.exerciseScores[exerciseId] = {
+       score,
+       totalQuestions,
+       percentage: Math.round((score / totalQuestions) * 100),
+       completedAt: new Date().toISOString()
+     };
+     localStorage.setItem(PROGRESS_KEY, JSON.stringify(progress));
+   },
+ 
+   // Get exercise score
+   getExerciseScore(exerciseId) {
+     const progress = this.getProgress() || this.initProgress();
+     return progress.exerciseScores[exerciseId] || null;
+   },
+ 
+   // Set current lesson
+   setCurrentLesson(lessonId) {
+     const progress = this.getProgress() || this.initProgress();
+     progress.currentLesson = lessonId;
+     progress.lastAccessed = new Date().toISOString();
+     localStorage.setItem(PROGRESS_KEY, JSON.stringify(progress));
+   },
+ 
+   // Get current lesson
+   getCurrentLesson() {
+     const progress = this.getProgress() || this.initProgress();
+     return progress.currentLesson;
+   },
+ 
+   // Calculate overall progress percentage
+   calculateProgress(totalLessons) {
+     const progress = this.getProgress() || this.initProgress();
+     const completed = progress.completedLessons.length;
+     return totalLessons &gt; 0 ? Math.round((completed / totalLessons) * 100) : 0;
+   },
+ 
+   // Get module progress
+   getModuleProgress(moduleId, lessons) {
+     const progress = this.getProgress() || this.initProgress();
+     const moduleLessons = lessons.filter(lesson =&gt; 
+       lesson.id.startsWith(moduleId)
+     );
+     const completed = moduleLessons.filter(lesson =&gt;
+       progress.completedLessons.includes(lesson.id)
+     ).length;
+     return {
+       completed,
+       total: moduleLessons.length,
+       percentage: moduleLessons.length &gt; 0 ? Math.round((completed / moduleLessons.length) * 100) : 0
+     };
+   },
+ 
+   // Reset all progress
+   resetProgress() {
+     localStorage.removeItem(PROGRESS_KEY);
+     return this.initProgress();
+   }
+ };
+ 
```

+ import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';
+ import { BrowserRouter as Router, Routes, Route, Navigate } from 'react-router-dom';
+ import { courseData } from './data/courseData';
+ import { progressTracker } from './utils/progressTracker';
+ import Dashboard from './components/Dashboard';
+ import ModuleView from './components/ModuleView';
+ import LessonView from './components/LessonView';
+ import Header from './components/Header';
+ 
+ function App() {
+   const [progress, setProgress] = useState(null);
+ 
+   useEffect(() =&gt; {
+     // Initialize progress on load
+     const initialProgress = progressTracker.initProgress();
+     setProgress(initialProgress);
+   }, []);
+ 
+   const refreshProgress = () =&gt; {
+     setProgress(progressTracker.getProgress());
+   };
+ 
+   if (!progress) {
+     return &lt;div className="loading"&gt;Loading...&lt;/div&gt;;
+   }
+ 
+   return (
+     &lt;Router&gt;
+       &lt;div className="app"&gt;
+         &lt;Header courseTitle={courseData.courseTitle} /&gt;
+         &lt;main className="main-content"&gt;
+           &lt;Routes&gt;
+             &lt;Route 
+               path="/" 
+               element={
+                 &lt;Dashboard 
+                   courseData={courseData} 
+                   progress={progress}
+                   refreshProgress={refreshProgress}
+                 /&gt;
+               } 
+             /&gt;
+             &lt;Route 
+               path="/module/:moduleId" 
+               element={
+                 &lt;ModuleView 
+                   courseData={courseData}
+                   progress={progress}
+                   refreshProgress={refreshProgress}
+                 /&gt;
+               } 
+             /&gt;
+             &lt;Route 
+               path="/lesson/:lessonId" 
+               element={
+                 &lt;LessonView 
+                   courseData={courseData}
+                   progress={progress}
+                   refreshProgress={refreshProgress}
+                 /&gt;
+               } 
+             /&gt;
+             &lt;Route path="*" element={&lt;Navigate to="/" /&gt;} /&gt;
+           &lt;/Routes&gt;
+         &lt;/main&gt;
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+     &lt;/Router&gt;
+   );
+ }
+ 
+ export default App;
+

+ import React from 'react';
+ import { Link } from 'react-router-dom';
+ import { progressTracker } from '../utils/progressTracker';
+ 
+ function Dashboard({ courseData, progress, refreshProgress }) {
+   // Calculate total lessons
+   const totalLessons = courseData.modules.reduce((total, module) =&gt; {
+     return total + module.chapters.reduce((chapterTotal, chapter) =&gt; {
+       return chapterTotal + chapter.lessons.length;
+     }, 0);
+   }, 0);
+ 
+   const overallProgress = progressTracker.calculateProgress(totalLessons);
+ 
+   // Get all lessons for module progress calculation
+   const getAllLessons = (moduleId) =&gt; {
+     const module = courseData.modules.find(m =&gt; m.id === moduleId);
+     if (!module) return [];
+     return module.chapters.flatMap(chapter =&gt; chapter.lessons);
+   };
+ 
+   return (
+     &lt;div className="dashboard"&gt;
+       &lt;section className="welcome-section"&gt;
+         &lt;h2&gt;Welcome to English Language Arts&lt;/h2&gt;
+         &lt;p className="course-description"&gt;{courseData.description}&lt;/p&gt;
+         &lt;div className="progress-overview"&gt;
+           &lt;div className="progress-stat"&gt;
+             &lt;span className="stat-value"&gt;{progress.completedLessons.length}&lt;/span&gt;
+             &lt;span className="stat-label"&gt;Lessons Completed&lt;/span&gt;
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+           &lt;div className="progress-stat"&gt;
+             &lt;span className="stat-value"&gt;{overallProgress}%&lt;/span&gt;
+             &lt;span className="stat-label"&gt;Overall Progress&lt;/span&gt;
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+           &lt;div className="progress-stat"&gt;
+             &lt;span className="stat-value"&gt;{Object.keys(progress.exerciseScores).length}&lt;/span&gt;
+             &lt;span className="stat-label"&gt;Exercises Completed&lt;/span&gt;
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+         &lt;div className="progress-bar-container"&gt;
+           &lt;div className="progress-bar"&gt;
+             &lt;div 
+               className="progress-bar-fill" 
+               style={{ width: &#96;${overallProgress}%&#96; }}
+             /&gt;
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+           &lt;span className="progress-text"&gt;{overallProgress}% Complete&lt;/span&gt;
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+       &lt;/section&gt;
+ 
+       &lt;section className="modules-section"&gt;
+         &lt;h2&gt;Course Modules&lt;/h2&gt;
+         &lt;div className="modules-grid"&gt;
+           {courseData.modules.map(module =&gt; {
+             const moduleLessons = getAllLessons(module.id);

+

+               &lt;Link 
+                 to={&#96;/module/${module.id}&#96;} 
+                 key={module.id} 
+                 className="module-card"
+               &gt;
+                 &lt;div className="module-icon"&gt;{module.icon}&lt;/div&gt;
+                 &lt;h3&gt;{module.title}&lt;/h3&gt;
+                 &lt;p className="module-description"&gt;{module.description}&lt;/p&gt;
+                 &lt;div className="module-stats"&gt;
+                   &lt;span className="chapter-count"&gt;
+                     {module.chapters.length} Chapter{module.chapters.length !== 1 ? 's' : ''}
+                   &lt;/span&gt;
+                   &lt;span className="lesson-count"&gt;

+                 &lt;/div&gt;
+                 &lt;div className="module-progress"&gt;
+                   &lt;div className="progress-bar small"&gt;

+ import React from 'react';

+ function ModuleView({ courseData, progress }) {

+

+     &lt;div className="module-view"&gt;

+             progressTracker.isLessonCompleted(lesson.id)
+           ).length;

+                 &lt;/span&gt;
+               &lt;/div&gt;
+

<details><summary>Tool use: **write** ‚Ä¢ Edit file: /Users/nputti/English Tutor/src/components/LessonView.jsx</summary>

**Chunk 1**

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,139 @@
- 
+ import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';
+ import { useParams, Link, useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom';
+ import { progressTracker } from '../utils/progressTracker';
+ import LessonContent from './LessonContent';
+ import ExerciseContent from './ExerciseContent';
+ 
+ function LessonView({ courseData, progress, refreshProgress }) {
+   const { lessonId } = useParams();
+   const navigate = useNavigate();
+   const [lesson, setLesson] = useState(null);
+   const [module, setModule] = useState(null);
+   const [chapter, setChapter] = useState(null);
+   const [nextLesson, setNextLesson] = useState(null);
+   const [prevLesson, setPrevLesson] = useState(null);
+ 
+   useEffect(() =&gt; {
+     // Find the lesson, module, and chapter
+     let foundLesson = null;
+     let foundModule = null;
+     let foundChapter = null;
+ 
+     for (const mod of courseData.modules) {
+       for (const chap of mod.chapters) {
+         const les = chap.lessons.find(l =&gt; l.id === lessonId);
+         if (les) {
+           foundLesson = les;
+           foundModule = mod;
+           foundChapter = chap;
+           break;
+         }
+       }
+       if (foundLesson) break;
+     }
+ 
+     if (foundLesson) {
+       setLesson(foundLesson);
+       setModule(foundModule);
+       setChapter(foundChapter);
+ 
+       // Find next and previous lessons
+       const allLessons = [];
+       courseData.modules.forEach(mod =&gt; {
+         mod.chapters.forEach(chap =&gt; {
+           allLessons.push(...chap.lessons);
+         });
+       });
+ 
+       const currentIndex = allLessons.findIndex(l =&gt; l.id === lessonId);
+       if (currentIndex &gt; 0) {
+         setPrevLesson(allLessons[currentIndex - 1]);
+       }
+       if (currentIndex &lt; allLessons.length - 1) {
+         setNextLesson(allLessons[currentIndex + 1]);
+       }
+ 
+       // Set as current lesson
+       progressTracker.setCurrentLesson(lessonId);
+     }
+   }, [lessonId, courseData]);
+ 
+   const handleComplete = () =&gt; {
+     progressTracker.completeLesson(lessonId);
+     refreshProgress();
+     if (nextLesson) {
+       navigate(&#96;/lesson/${nextLesson.id}&#96;);
+     } else {
+       navigate(&#96;/module/${module.id}&#96;);
+     }
+   };
+ 
+   if (!lesson || !module || !chapter) {
+     return (
+       &lt;div className="error-page"&gt;
+         &lt;h2&gt;Lesson not found&lt;/h2&gt;
+         &lt;Link to="/" className="btn btn-primary"&gt;Back to Dashboard&lt;/Link&gt;
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+     );
+   }
+ 
+   const isCompleted = progressTracker.isLessonCompleted(lessonId);
+ 
+   return (
+     &lt;div className="lesson-view"&gt;
+       &lt;div className="lesson-header"&gt;
+         &lt;Link to={&#96;/module/${module.id}&#96;} className="back-link"&gt;
+           ‚Üê Back to {module.title}
+         &lt;/Link&gt;
+         &lt;div className="lesson-breadcrumb"&gt;
+           &lt;span&gt;{module.title}&lt;/span&gt;
+           &lt;span className="separator"&gt;/&lt;/span&gt;
+           &lt;span&gt;{chapter.title}&lt;/span&gt;
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+       &lt;div className="lesson-container"&gt;
+         &lt;div className="lesson-title-section"&gt;
+           &lt;h1&gt;{lesson.title}&lt;/h1&gt;
+           &lt;span className={&#96;lesson-type-badge ${lesson.type}&#96;}&gt;
+             {lesson.type === 'lesson' ? 'üìñ Lesson' : '‚úèÔ∏è Exercise'}
+           &lt;/span&gt;
+           {isCompleted &amp;&amp; (
+             &lt;span className="completion-badge large"&gt;‚úì Completed&lt;/span&gt;
+           )}
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+         {lesson.type === 'lesson' ? (
+           &lt;LessonContent 
+             content={lesson.content}
+             onComplete={handleComplete}
+             isCompleted={isCompleted}
+           /&gt;
+         ) : (
+           &lt;ExerciseContent
+             lessonId={lesson.id}
+             content={lesson.content}
+             onComplete={handleComplete}
+             refreshProgress={refreshProgress}
+           /&gt;
+         )}
+ 
+         &lt;div className="lesson-navigation"&gt;
+           {prevLesson &amp;&amp; (
+             &lt;Link to={&#96;/lesson/${prevLesson.id}&#96;} className="nav-btn prev"&gt;
+               ‚Üê Previous: {prevLesson.title}
+             &lt;/Link&gt;
+           )}
+           {nextLesson &amp;&amp; (
+             &lt;Link to={&#96;/lesson/${nextLesson.id}&#96;} className="nav-btn next"&gt;
+               Next: {nextLesson.title} ‚Üí
+             &lt;/Link&gt;
+           )}
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+     &lt;/div&gt;
+   );
+ }
+ 
+ export default LessonView;
+ 
```

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,65 @@
- 
+ import React from 'react';
+ 
+ function LessonContent({ content, onComplete, isCompleted }) {
+   return (
+     &lt;div className="lesson-content"&gt;
+       &lt;div className="content-section"&gt;
+         &lt;div className="introduction"&gt;
+           &lt;h2&gt;Introduction&lt;/h2&gt;
+           &lt;p&gt;{content.introduction}&lt;/p&gt;
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+         &lt;div className="explanation"&gt;
+           &lt;h2&gt;Explanation&lt;/h2&gt;
+           &lt;div className="explanation-text"&gt;
+             {content.explanation.split('\n').map((paragraph, index) =&gt; {
+               // Handle bold text with **
+               const formattedParagraph = paragraph.split('**').map((part, i) =&gt; {
+                 if (i % 2 === 1) {
+                   return &lt;strong key={i}&gt;{part}&lt;/strong&gt;;
+                 }
+                 return part;
+               });
+               
+               return paragraph.trim() ? (
+                 &lt;p key={index}&gt;{formattedParagraph}&lt;/p&gt;
+               ) : null;
+             })}
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+         {content.examples &amp;&amp; content.examples.length &gt; 0 &amp;&amp; (
+           &lt;div className="examples"&gt;
+             &lt;h2&gt;Examples&lt;/h2&gt;
+             {content.examples.map((example, index) =&gt; (
+               &lt;div key={index} className="example-card"&gt;
+                 &lt;div className="example-text"&gt;
+                   {example.text}
+                 &lt;/div&gt;
+                 &lt;div className="example-explanation"&gt;
+                   &lt;strong&gt;Explanation:&lt;/strong&gt; {example.explanation}
+                 &lt;/div&gt;
+               &lt;/div&gt;
+             ))}
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+         )}
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+       &lt;div className="lesson-actions"&gt;
+         {!isCompleted ? (
+           &lt;button onClick={onComplete} className="btn btn-primary"&gt;
+             Mark as Complete
+           &lt;/button&gt;
+         ) : (
+           &lt;div className="completed-message"&gt;
+             &lt;span className="completion-icon"&gt;‚úì&lt;/span&gt;
+             You've completed this lesson!
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+         )}
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+     &lt;/div&gt;
+   );
+ }
+ 
+ export default LessonContent;
+

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,195 @@
- 
+ import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';
+ import { progressTracker } from '../utils/progressTracker';
+ 
+ function ExerciseContent({ lessonId, content, onComplete, refreshProgress }) {
+   const [currentQuestion, setCurrentQuestion] = useState(0);
+   const [selectedAnswers, setSelectedAnswers] = useState({});
+   const [showResults, setShowResults] = useState(false);
+   const [score, setScore] = useState(0);
+ 
+   const existingScore = progressTracker.getExerciseScore(lessonId);
+ 
+   useEffect(() =&gt; {
+     // If exercise was already completed, show results
+     if (existingScore) {
+       setShowResults(true);
+       setScore(existingScore.score);
+     }
+   }, [existingScore]);
+ 
+   const questions = content.questions || [];
+   const hasPassage = content.passage;
+ 
+   const handleAnswerSelect = (questionId, answerIndex) =&gt; {
+     if (showResults) return; // Don't allow changes after submission
+     
+     setSelectedAnswers({
+       ...selectedAnswers,
+       [questionId]: answerIndex
+     });
+   };
+ 
+   const handleSubmit = () =&gt; {
+     let correctCount = 0;
+     questions.forEach(question =&gt; {
+       const selectedAnswer = selectedAnswers[question.id];
+       if (selectedAnswer === question.correctAnswer) {
+         correctCount++;
+       }
+     });
+ 
+     setScore(correctCount);
+     setShowResults(true);
+ 
+     // Save score to progress
+     progressTracker.saveExerciseScore(lessonId, correctCount, questions.length);
+     progressTracker.completeLesson(lessonId);
+     refreshProgress();
+   };
+ 
+   const handleRetry = () =&gt; {
+     setSelectedAnswers({});
+     setShowResults(false);
+     setScore(0);
+     setCurrentQuestion(0);
+   };
+ 
+   const isAnswered = (questionId) =&gt; {
+     return selectedAnswers.hasOwnProperty(questionId);
+   };
+ 
+   const allAnswered = questions.every(q =&gt; isAnswered(q.id));
+ 
+   const percentage = Math.round((score / questions.length) * 100);
+ 
+   return (
+     &lt;div className="exercise-content"&gt;
+       &lt;div className="exercise-instructions"&gt;
+         &lt;h2&gt;Instructions&lt;/h2&gt;
+         &lt;p&gt;{content.instructions}&lt;/p&gt;
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+       {hasPassage &amp;&amp; (
+         &lt;div className="reading-passage"&gt;
+           &lt;h3&gt;Reading Passage&lt;/h3&gt;
+           &lt;div className="passage-text"&gt;
+             {content.passage}
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+       )}
+ 
+       &lt;div className="questions-container"&gt;
+         {questions.map((question, index) =&gt; {
+           const isSelected = isAnswered(question.id);
+           const selectedAnswer = selectedAnswers[question.id];
+           const isCorrect = selectedAnswer === question.correctAnswer;
+ 
+           return (
+             &lt;div key={question.id} className="question-card"&gt;
+               &lt;div className="question-header"&gt;
+                 &lt;span className="question-number"&gt;Question {index + 1}&lt;/span&gt;
+                 {showResults &amp;&amp; (
+                   &lt;span className={&#96;result-badge ${isCorrect ? 'correct' : 'incorrect'}&#96;}&gt;
+                     {isCorrect ? '‚úì Correct' : '‚úó Incorrect'}
+                   &lt;/span&gt;
+                 )}
+               &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+               &lt;div className="question-text"&gt;
+                 {question.passage &amp;&amp; (
+                   &lt;div className="question-passage"&gt;
+                     &lt;em&gt;{question.passage}&lt;/em&gt;
+                   &lt;/div&gt;
+                 )}
+                 {question.word &amp;&amp; (
+                   &lt;div className="question-word"&gt;
+                     Word: &lt;strong&gt;{question.word}&lt;/strong&gt;
+                   &lt;/div&gt;
+                 )}
+                 &lt;p&gt;{question.question}&lt;/p&gt;
+               &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+               &lt;div className="answer-options"&gt;
+                 {question.options.map((option, optionIndex) =&gt; {
+                   const isThisSelected = selectedAnswer === optionIndex;
+                   const isThisCorrect = optionIndex === question.correctAnswer;
+                   
+                   let optionClass = 'answer-option';
+                   if (showResults) {
+                     if (isThisCorrect) {
+                       optionClass += ' correct';
+                     } else if (isThisSelected &amp;&amp; !isThisCorrect) {
+                       optionClass += ' incorrect';
+                     }
+                   } else if (isThisSelected) {
+                     optionClass += ' selected';
+                   }
+ 
+                   return (
+                     &lt;button
+                       key={optionIndex}
+                       className={optionClass}
+                       onClick={() =&gt; handleAnswerSelect(question.id, optionIndex)}
+                       disabled={showResults}
+                     &gt;
+                       &lt;span className="option-letter"&gt;
+                         {String.fromCharCode(65 + optionIndex)}.
+                       &lt;/span&gt;
+                       &lt;span className="option-text"&gt;{option}&lt;/span&gt;
+                       {showResults &amp;&amp; isThisCorrect &amp;&amp; (
+                         &lt;span className="check-icon"&gt;‚úì&lt;/span&gt;
+                       )}
+                     &lt;/button&gt;
+                   );
+                 })}
+               &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+               {showResults &amp;&amp; (
+                 &lt;div className="explanation-box"&gt;
+                   &lt;strong&gt;Explanation:&lt;/strong&gt; {question.explanation}
+                 &lt;/div&gt;
+               )}
+             &lt;/div&gt;
+           );
+         })}
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+ 
+       &lt;div className="exercise-actions"&gt;
+         {!showResults ? (
+           &lt;button
+             onClick={handleSubmit}
+             className="btn btn-primary"
+             disabled={!allAnswered}
+           &gt;
+             {allAnswered ? 'Submit Answers' : &#96;Answer all questions (${Object.keys(selectedAnswers).length}/${questions.length})&#96;}
+           &lt;/button&gt;
+         ) : (
+           &lt;div className="results-section"&gt;
+             &lt;div className="score-display"&gt;
+               &lt;div className={&#96;score-circle ${percentage &gt;= 70 ? 'pass' : 'needs-improvement'}&#96;}&gt;
+                 &lt;span className="score-percentage"&gt;{percentage}%&lt;/span&gt;
+                 &lt;span className="score-fraction"&gt;{score}/{questions.length}&lt;/span&gt;
+               &lt;/div&gt;
+               &lt;div className="score-message"&gt;
+                 {percentage &gt;= 90 &amp;&amp; &lt;p&gt;üåü Excellent work! You've mastered this topic!&lt;/p&gt;}
+                 {percentage &gt;= 70 &amp;&amp; percentage &lt; 90 &amp;&amp; &lt;p&gt;‚úì Good job! You have a solid understanding.&lt;/p&gt;}
+                 {percentage &lt; 70 &amp;&amp; &lt;p&gt;Keep practicing! Review the lesson and try again.&lt;/p&gt;}
+               &lt;/div&gt;
+             &lt;/div&gt;
+             &lt;div className="results-actions"&gt;
+               &lt;button onClick={handleRetry} className="btn btn-secondary"&gt;
+                 Try Again
+               &lt;/button&gt;
+               &lt;button onClick={onComplete} className="btn btn-primary"&gt;
+                 Continue to Next Lesson
+               &lt;/button&gt;
+             &lt;/div&gt;
+           &lt;/div&gt;
+         )}
+       &lt;/div&gt;
+     &lt;/div&gt;
+   );
+ }
+ 
+ export default ExerciseContent;
+ 
```

+ # English Language Arts - Grade 6 Interactive Course
+ 
+ A comprehensive, interactive web-based English Language Arts course designed for Grade 6 students following the California curriculum. This platform covers Vocabulary, Grammar, Reading Comprehension, and Writing with progress tracking and interactive exercises.
+ 
+ ## Features
+ 
+ ### üìö Comprehensive Curriculum
+ - **Vocabulary**: Context clues, word roots, Greek and Latin origins
+ - **Grammar**: Parts of speech, sentence structure, and language mechanics
+ - **Reading Comprehension**: Main ideas, supporting details, and making inferences
+ - **Writing**: Paragraph structure, narrative writing, and composition skills
+ 
+ ### üéØ Interactive Learning
+ - Engaging lessons with clear explanations and examples
+ - Practice exercises with immediate feedback
+ - Multiple-choice questions with detailed explanations
+ - Reading passages with comprehension questions
+ 
+ ### üìä Progress Tracking
+ - Track completed lessons and exercises
+ - View scores and performance statistics
+ - Monitor progress across all modules
+ - Resume where you left off
+ 
+ ### üé® Modern Interface
+ - Clean, intuitive design
+ - Responsive layout for all devices
+ - Easy navigation between chapters and lessons
+ - Visual progress indicators
+ 
+ ## Getting Started
+ 
+ ### Prerequisites
+ - Node.js (version 14 or higher)
+ - npm (comes with Node.js)
+ 
+ ### Installation
+ 
+ 1. Navigate to the project directory:
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+ cd "/Users/nputti/English Tutor"
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ 2. Install dependencies:
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+ npm install
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ 3. Start the development server:
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+ npm run dev
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ 4. Open your browser and navigate to:
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ http://localhost:3000
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ## Project Structure
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ English Tutor/
+ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
+ ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/         # React components

+ 
+ ## Course Content
+ 
+ ### Module 1: Vocabulary
+ - **Chapter 1**: Context Clues
+   - Understanding different types of context clues
+   - Practice exercises with real-world examples
+   
+ - **Chapter 2**: Word Roots and Affixes
+   - Greek and Latin roots
+   - Building vocabulary through word analysis
+ 
+ ### Module 2: Grammar
+ - **Chapter 1**: Parts of Speech
+   - Nouns, pronouns, and verbs
+   - Identifying parts of speech in context
+   
+ - **Chapter 2**: Sentence Structure
+   - Simple and compound sentences
+   - Proper punctuation and conjunctions
+ 
+ ### Module 3: Reading Comprehension
+ - **Chapter 1**: Main Idea and Supporting Details
+   - Finding the main idea
+   - Identifying supporting evidence
+   
+ - **Chapter 2**: Making Inferences
+   - Reading between the lines
+   - Drawing conclusions from text
+ 
+ ### Module 4: Writing
+ - **Chapter 1**: Paragraph Structure
+   - Topic sentences and supporting details
+   - Writing cohesive paragraphs
+   
+ - **Chapter 2**: Narrative Writing
+   - Story elements (characters, setting, plot)
+   - Point of view and dialogue
+ 
+ ## How to Use
+ 
+ ### For Students
+ 
+ 1. **Start at the Dashboard**: View all available modules and your overall progress
+ 
+ 2. **Select a Module**: Choose from Vocabulary, Grammar, Reading Comprehension, or Writing
+ 
+ 3. **Work Through Chapters**: Each module contains multiple chapters with lessons and exercises
+ 
+ 4. **Complete Lessons**: Read through lesson content with examples and explanations
+ 
+ 5. **Practice with Exercises**: Test your knowledge with interactive exercises
+    - Answer all questions
+    - Submit for immediate feedback
+    - Review explanations for each answer
+    - Retry exercises to improve your score
+ 
+ 6. **Track Progress**: Monitor your completion status and scores on the dashboard
+ 
+ ### For Educators/Parents
+ 
+ - Progress is saved locally in the browser
+ - Students can work at their own pace
+ - Exercises provide immediate feedback
+ - All content aligns with Grade 6 California standards
+ 
+ ## Customization
+ 
+ ### Adding New Content
+ 
+ To add new lessons or exercises, edit &#96;src/data/courseData.js&#96;:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;javascript
+ {
+   id: "unique-lesson-id",
+   title: "Lesson Title",
+   type: "lesson", // or "exercise"
+   content: {
+     // Add lesson/exercise content here
+   }
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### Modifying Styles
+ 
+ Edit &#96;src/styles/main.css&#96; to customize colors, fonts, and layout.
+ 
+ ## Technology Stack
+ 
+ - **React 18**: UI framework
+ - **React Router**: Navigation and routing
+ - **Vite**: Build tool and development server
+ - **CSS3**: Styling with custom properties
+ - **Local Storage**: Client-side progress tracking
+ 
+ ## Browser Support
+ 
+ - Chrome (latest)
+ - Firefox (latest)
+ - Safari (latest)
+ - Edge (latest)
+ 
+ ## Future Enhancements
+ 
+ Potential features for future versions:
+ - User authentication and cloud-based progress sync
+ - Additional modules (Speaking &amp; Listening, Research)
+ - More interactive exercise types (drag-and-drop, fill-in-blank)
+ - Printable worksheets
+ - Teacher dashboard for monitoring multiple students
+ - Gamification elements (badges, achievements)
+ 
+ ## License
+ 
+ This project is created for educational purposes.
+ 
+ ## Support
+ 
+ For questions or issues, please refer to the documentation or contact your instructor.

+               type: "lesson",
+               content: {
+                 introduction: "Figurative language helps writers create vivid images and express ideas in creative ways. Similes and metaphors are two common types of figurative language.",
+                 explanation: "**Simile**: A comparison between two unlike things using 'like' or 'as'\n- Example: She was as brave as a lion.\n- Example: The snow fell like a soft blanket.\n\n**Metaphor**: A direct comparison that says one thing IS another thing (without using 'like' or 'as')\n- Example: Time is money.\n- Example: Her smile was sunshine on a cloudy day.\n\n**Key Difference**: Similes use 'like' or 'as' to make comparisons, while metaphors make direct comparisons.\n\n**Why Use Them?**\n- Make writing more interesting and descriptive\n- Help readers visualize and understand ideas\n- Create emotional connections",

There are often subtle differences:\n- 'Happy' is general; 'ecstatic' is extremely happy\n- 'Big' is basic; 'colossal' suggests something impressively large\n\n**Antonyms**: Words with opposite meanings\n- Hot ‚Üî Cold\n- Fast ‚Üî Slow\n- Beginning ‚Üî End\n- Ancient ‚Üî Modern\n\n**Why They Matter:**\n- Avoid repetition in writing\n- Choose the most precise word for your meaning\n- Better understand what you read\n- Make your writing more interesting",

+                 explanation: "**Multiple Meaning Words** (also called homonyms or polysemous words) are words that have more than one definition.\n\n**Common Examples:**\n\n**Bank**\n- A place to keep money (noun)\n- The edge of a river (noun)\n- To tilt to one side (verb)\n\n**Bat**\n- A flying mammal (noun)\n- Equipment for hitting a ball (noun)\n- To hit something (verb)\n\n**Fair**\n- Treating people equally (adjective)\n- Light-colored (adjective)\n- A carnival or festival (noun)\n- Average, not bad (adjective)\n\n**Key**\n- Opens a lock (noun)\n- Important or essential (adjective)\n- A musical scale (noun)\n- A button on a keyboard (noun)\n\n**How to Determine Meaning:**\n1. Look at the context of the sentence\n2. Consider the part of speech (noun, verb, adjective)\n3. Think about what makes sense",

Understanding these helps you "unlock" the meaning of thousands of unfamiliar words.Bio (Life): Biology, Biography, BiosphereGraph (Write): Autograph, Paragraph, GraphicTele (Far): Telescope, Telephone, TelevisionMicro (Small): Microscope, Microbiome, MicrowavePre- (Before): Prefix, Predict, PrepareAnti- (Against): Antidote, Antisocial, Antiseptic3. Figurative Language & Literary TermsCalifornia standards require students to identify and use nuances in word meanings.Simile: A comparison using "like" or "as" (e.g., Quiet as a mouse).Metaphor: A direct comparison without using like/as (e.g., The snow is a white blanket).Personification: Giving human qualities to non-human things (e.g., The wind whistled).Hyperbole: An extreme exaggeration (e.g., I've told you a million times).Connotation: The feeling a word gives you (e.g., "Youthful" vs. "Childish").4. How to PracticeTo master these, I recommend the "Context, Clue, Connect" method:Context: Read the word in a full sentence.Clue: Look for prefixes or suffixes you recognize.Connect: Try to use the word in a sentence about your own life.Since you mentioned your interest in Grade 6 California standards.

              {
                id: "vocab-6-1",

+               title: "Word Meanings and Feelings - Understanding Nuances",
                type: "lesson",
                content: {
-                 introduction: "Words have two types of meanings: their dictionary definition (denotation) and the feelings or associations they carry (connotation).",
-                 explanation: "**Denotation**: The literal, dictionary definition of a word\n- Example: 'Home' denotes a place where someone lives\n\n**Connotation**: The emotional associations and feelings a word suggests\n- Example: 'Home' connotes warmth, safety, family, and comfort\n\n**Why This Matters:**\nWords with similar denotations can have very different connotations:\n\n**Example Set 1:**\n- Cheap (negative connotation: poor quality)\n- Inexpensive (neutral/positive: good value)\n- Economical (positive: wise spending)\n\nAll three mean 'low cost' but carry different feelings.\n\n**Example Set 2:**\n- Childish (negative: immature)\n- Childlike (positive: innocent, pure)\n- Youthful (positive: energetic, fresh)\n\n**Positive, Negative, or Neutral?**\nWriters choose words carefully based on the feeling they want to create.",
+                 introduction: "California Grade 6 standards require students to understand nuances in word meanings. Words have two types of meanings: their dictionary definition (denotation) and the feelings or associations they carry (connotation). This skill is critical for both understanding what you read and choosing the right words in your writing.",
+                 explanation: "**Denotation**: The literal, dictionary definition of a word\n- Example: 'Home' denotes a place where someone lives\n\n**Connotation**: The emotional associations and feelings a word suggests\n- Example: 'Home' connotes warmth, safety, family, and comfort\n\n**Understanding Nuances (Subtle Differences):**\nWords with similar denotations can have very different connotations. This is what we call 'nuances' - the subtle shades of meaning.\n\n**Example Set 1: Words about Being Careful with Money**\n- **Cheap** (negative: poor quality, unwilling to spend)\n- **Inexpensive** (neutral/positive: good value, affordable)\n- **Economical** (positive: wise spending, efficient)\n- **Thrifty** (positive: careful and resourceful)\n\n**Example Set 2: Words about Being Young**\n- **Childish** (negative: immature, silly)\n- **Childlike** (positive: innocent, pure, full of wonder)\n- **Youthful** (positive: energetic, fresh, vibrant)\n- **Immature** (negative: not fully developed, irresponsible)\n\n**Example Set 3: Words about Being Thin**\n- **Slender** (positive: gracefully thin)\n- **Skinny** (negative: too thin, unhealthily thin)\n- **Slim** (positive: attractively thin)\n- **Scrawny** (negative: thin and weak-looking)\n\n**The Connotation Scale:**\nPositive ‚Üí Neutral ‚Üí Negative\n\n**Why This Matters:**\n- Writers choose words carefully to create specific feelings\n- Understanding connotation helps you interpret what you read\n- Using words with the right connotation makes your writing more effective",
                  examples: [
                    {

_**User (2025-12-23 20:02Z)**_



Lets add chapters to grammer module based on below details:

In 6th grade, California‚Äôs grammar standards (CCSS) shift from basic sentence structure to the conventions of standard English that make writing more precise and sophisticated. The biggest focus this year is on pronouns and sentence variety.



Here are the key pillars of 6th-grade grammar in California:

1. Mastery of Pronouns

This is arguably the most important grammar goal for 6th graders. You are expected to:

Case: Ensure pronouns are in the proper case:

Subjective: I, he, she, we, they (The person doing the action).

Objective: Me, him, her, us, them (The person receiving the action).

Possessive: My, his, hers, ours, theirs.

Intensive Pronouns: Use pronouns like myself, ourselves, and themselves to add emphasis (e.g., "I did the homework myself.").

Vague Antecedents: Avoid "vague" pronouns where it's unclear who you are talking about.

Vague: "Sarah and Jane went to the store, and she bought milk." (Who is she?)

Correct: "Sarah and Jane went to the store; Sarah bought milk."

2. Punctuation for Clarity

California standards emphasize using punctuation to manage "extra" information in a sentence.

Parenthetical Elements: Use commas, parentheses, or dashes to set off non-essential information.

Example: "The principal**, Mr. Smith,** gave a speech."

Coordinate Adjectives: Use commas to separate adjectives that describe the same noun in an equal way.

Example: "It was a long, exhausting day." (You can tell they are coordinate because you could say "long and exhausting").

3. Sentence Patterns and Style

By 6th grade, the goal is to stop writing "choppy" sentences and start varying your style.

Simple, Compound, and Complex Sentences: You should be able to move between these to show how ideas relate.

Consistency: Maintain a consistent style and tone. If you start a formal essay, you shouldn't suddenly use slang or "text speak."

4. Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Grade 6 is the year to "clean up" common errors:

Pronoun Shifts: Don't switch from "I" to "you" or "one" in the middle of a paragraph.

Misplaced Modifiers: Ensure descriptive phrases are next to the word they describe.

Incorrect: "I saw a dog wearing a hat walking down the street." (Was the hat walking down the street?)

Correct: "While walking down the street, I saw a dog wearing a hat."

Grammar Check-In

Which of these sounds most challenging to you right now?

Choosing between "I" and "me" in complex sentences.

Knowing when to use a comma vs. a dash.

Understanding the difference between a phrase and a clause.

+               title: "Pronoun Case: Subjective, Objective, and Possessive",
+               type: "lesson",
+               content: {
+                 introduction: "Mastering pronouns is arguably the most important grammar goal for 6th graders in California. Understanding pronoun case ensures your writing is clear and correct.",
+                 explanation: "**Three Types of Pronoun Case:**\n\n**1. Subjective Case (Subject Pronouns)**\nUse when the pronoun is doing the action:\n- **Pronouns**: I, he, she, we, they\n- Example: **She** went to the store. (She is doing the action)\n- Example: **We** finished our homework. (We are doing the action)\n\n**2. Objective Case (Object Pronouns)**\nUse when the pronoun is receiving the action:\n- **Pronouns**: me, him, her, us, them\n- Example: The teacher called **me**. (Me is receiving the action)\n- Example: Dad drove **us** to school. (Us is receiving the action)\n\n**3. Possessive Case (Possessive Pronouns)**\nUse to show ownership:\n- **Pronouns**: my, mine, his, her, hers, our, ours, their, theirs, its\n- Example: That book is **mine**.\n- Example: **Their** project won first place.\n\n**Common Trouble Spots:**\n\n**Problem 1: Compound Subjects and Objects**\n- Wrong: \"Me and John went to the park.\"\n- Right: \"**John and I** went to the park.\" (Remove \"John\" - would you say \"Me went\"?)\n\n- Wrong: \"The coach picked John and I for the team.\"\n- Right: \"The coach picked **John and me** for the team.\" (Remove \"John\" - would you say \"picked I\"?)\n\n**Tip**: Remove the other person and see which pronoun sounds correct!\n\n**Problem 2: After Prepositions (to, for, with, between, etc.)**\nAlways use objective case after prepositions:\n- Wrong: \"Between you and I...\"\n- Right: \"Between you and **me**...\"\n- Wrong: \"Come with Sarah and I.\"\n- Right: \"Come with Sarah and **me**.\"",
+                 examples: [
+                   {
+                     text: "Wrong: 'The prize went to Maria and I.' | Right: 'The prize went to Maria and me.'",
+                     explanation: "After the preposition 'to,' we need the objective case 'me.' Test: Would you say 'to I'? No, you'd say 'to me.'"
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "Wrong: 'Her and I studied together.' | Right: 'She and I studied together.'",
+                     explanation: "As the subject doing the action (studying), we need subjective case 'She and I.'"
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "The book is mine, and the pencil is hers.",
+                     explanation: "Both 'mine' and 'hers' are possessive pronouns showing ownership."

Look for clues in the text\n2. Think about what you already know\n3. Combine them to reach a logical conclusion\n4. Check if your inference makes sense with the entire passage",

+           id: "grammar-4",
+           title: "Chapter 4: Mastering Pronouns - Part 2",
+           lessons: [
+             {
+               id: "grammar-4-1",
+               title: "Intensive Pronouns and Clear Antecedents",
+               type: "lesson",
+               content: {
+                 introduction: "Beyond basic pronoun case, Grade 6 students must master intensive pronouns for emphasis and ensure all pronouns have clear antecedents (the nouns they refer to).",
+                 explanation: "**Intensive Pronouns (Adding Emphasis)**\n\nIntensive pronouns add emphasis to a noun or pronoun:\n- **Forms**: myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves\n\n**Examples:**\n- I did the homework **myself**. (I did it, no one else)\n- The principal **herself** announced the winners. (emphasizes it was the principal, not someone else)\n- We built the treehouse **ourselves**. (emphasizes we did it without help)\n\n**Key Rule**: Intensive pronouns emphasize who did something. They are NOT required for the sentence to make sense.\n- Test: Remove the intensive pronoun - the sentence still works.\n- \"I did the homework\" still makes sense without \"myself.\"\n\n**Common Mistake:**\n- Wrong: \"Myself and Tom went to the game.\"\n- Right: \"Tom and I went to the game.\" (Don't use 'myself' as a subject!)\n\n---\n\n**Clear Antecedents (Avoiding Vague Pronouns)**\n\nAn **antecedent** is the noun that a pronoun refers to. Every pronoun must have a clear antecedent!\n\n**Problem: Vague Pronoun Reference**\nWhen it's unclear who or what a pronoun refers to:\n\n**Example 1:**\n- **Vague**: \"Sarah and Jane went to the store, and **she** bought milk.\"\n  - Problem: Who is \"she\"? Sarah or Jane?\n- **Clear**: \"Sarah and Jane went to the store, and **Sarah** bought milk.\"\n- **Better**: \"Sarah and Jane went to the store; Sarah bought milk.\"\n\n**Example 2:**\n- **Vague**: \"After I put the vase on the shelf, **it** broke.\"\n  - Problem: What broke? The vase or the shelf?\n- **Clear**: \"After I put the vase on the shelf, **the vase** broke.\"\n\n**Example 3:**\n- **Vague**: \"In the article, **they** say pollution is increasing.\"\n  - Problem: Who is \"they\"?\n- **Clear**: \"In the article, **scientists** say pollution is increasing.\"\n\n**Rules for Clear Pronouns:**\n1. Make sure every pronoun clearly refers to ONE specific noun\n2. When in doubt, repeat the noun instead of using a pronoun\n3. Place pronouns close to their antecedents\n4. Avoid using \"they\" without a clear antecedent",
+                 examples: [
+                   {
+                     text: "The director himself approved the final script.",
+                     explanation: "The intensive pronoun 'himself' emphasizes that the director personally approved it."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "Vague: 'Tom told Alex that he needed to study more.' | Clear: 'Tom told Alex, \"You need to study more.\"'",
+                     explanation: "Who needs to study - Tom or Alex? Using direct dialogue or the person's name makes it clear."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "Vague: 'When I walked my dog, it was beautiful.' | Clear: 'When I walked my dog, the weather was beautiful.'",
+                     explanation: "What was beautiful? The dog or the weather? Repeating the noun clarifies the meaning."
+                   }
+                 ]
+               }
+             },

+         {
+           id: "grammar-5",
+           title: "Chapter 5: Punctuation for Clarity",
+           lessons: [
+             {
+               id: "grammar-5-1",
+               title: "Parenthetical Elements and Coordinate Adjectives",
+               type: "lesson",
+               content: {
+                 introduction: "California Grade 6 standards emphasize using punctuation to manage extra information in sentences. Learning to punctuate parenthetical elements and coordinate adjectives makes your writing clearer and more sophisticated.",
+                 explanation: "**Parenthetical Elements (Non-Essential Information)**\n\nParenthetical elements are extra pieces of information that can be removed without changing the basic meaning of the sentence. You can set them off with:\n- **Commas** (most common)\n- **Parentheses** (for very extra information)\n- **Dashes** (for emphasis)\n\n**Using Commas for Parenthetical Elements:**\n\n**Example 1: Appositives (Renaming Phrases)**\n- The principal**, Mr. Smith,** gave a speech.\n- My friend**, the one with red hair,** loves soccer.\n- California**, the Golden State,** is known for its beaches.\n\n**Example 2: Non-Essential Clauses**\n- My teacher**, who has taught for 20 years,** is very experienced.\n- The movie**, which won three awards,** was excellent.\n\n**Test**: Remove the information between commas - does the sentence still make sense?\n- \"The principal gave a speech.\" ‚úì Still works!\n\n**Using Parentheses:**\nFor information that's really \"extra\" or an aside:\n- The test **(which covers chapters 1-5)** is on Friday.\n- My dog **(a golden retriever)** loves to swim.\n\n**Using Dashes:**\nFor information you want to emphasize:\n- The winner**‚Äîmy best friend‚Äî**was announced on stage.\n- The assignment**‚Äîthe most difficult one yet‚Äî**is due Monday.\n\n---\n\n**Coordinate Adjectives**\n\nCoordinate adjectives are two or more adjectives that **equally** describe the same noun. Use commas to separate them.\n\n**The Test**: Can you:\n1. Put \"and\" between the adjectives? AND\n2. Reverse the order?\n\nIf YES to both, use a comma!\n\n**Examples:**\n- It was a long**, **exhausting day.\n  - Test: \"long and exhausting day\" ‚úì | \"exhausting, long day\" ‚úì\n  - Use comma!\n\n- She is a talented**, **dedicated student.\n  - Test: \"talented and dedicated\" ‚úì | \"dedicated, talented\" ‚úì\n  - Use comma!\n\n**When NOT to Use a Comma:**\nIf adjectives are not coordinate (one modifies the other):\n\n- I bought a small red car.\n  - Test: \"small and red car\"? Sounds awkward.\n  - Test: \"red small car\"? Sounds wrong.\n  - NO comma! \"Small\" modifies \"red car\" as a unit.\n\n- She wore a beautiful silk dress.\n  - Test: \"beautiful and silk\"? Doesn't work.\n  - NO comma! \"Beautiful\" modifies \"silk dress.\"",
+                 examples: [
+                   {
+                     text: "My brother, who is in college, visits every weekend.",
+                     explanation: "The phrase 'who is in college' is parenthetical (extra info) and is set off with commas."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "The final exam‚Äîthe hardest one all year‚Äîwill cover everything.",
+                     explanation: "Dashes emphasize the parenthetical information about the exam being the hardest."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "It was a cold, rainy November morning.",
+                     explanation: "Cold and rainy are coordinate adjectives (cold and rainy works; rainy, cold works), so use a comma."
+                   }
+                 ]
+               }
+             },
+             {
+               id: "grammar-5-2",
+               title: "Practice: Punctuation for Clarity",
+               type: "exercise",
+               content: {
+                 instructions: "Choose the correctly punctuated sentence or identify whether commas are needed.",

+                       "The principal Mr. Smith gave a speech.",

+                       "The principal Mr. Smith, gave a speech."
+                     ],
+                     correctAnswer: 2,
+                     explanation: "The appositive 'Mr. Smith' renames the principal and should be set off with commas on both sides."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     id: "q2",
+                     question: "Do these adjectives need a comma? 'It was a long exhausting journey.'",
+                     options: [
+                       "Yes - they are coordinate adjectives",
+                       "No - they are not coordinate adjectives",
+                       "Use a semicolon instead",
+                       "Use a dash instead"
+                     ],
+                     correctAnswer: 0,
+                     explanation: "Yes! Test: 'long and exhausting journey' ‚úì | 'exhausting, long journey' ‚úì. Both work, so use a comma."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     id: "q3",
+                     question: "Which sentence is punctuated correctly?",
+                     options: [
+                       "The movie which won five awards was amazing.",
+                       "The movie, which won five awards was amazing.",
+                       "The movie, which won five awards, was amazing.",
+                       "The movie which, won five awards, was amazing."
+                     ],
+                     correctAnswer: 2,
+                     explanation: "The clause 'which won five awards' is non-essential information and should be set off with commas on both sides."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     id: "q4",
+                     question: "Do these adjectives need a comma? 'She bought a beautiful silver bracelet.'",
+                     options: [
+                       "Yes - they are coordinate adjectives",
+                       "No - they are not coordinate adjectives",
+                       "Use parentheses instead",
+                       "Use dashes instead"
+                     ],
+                     correctAnswer: 1,
+                     explanation: "No comma. Test: 'beautiful and silver bracelet' sounds awkward. 'Beautiful' modifies 'silver bracelet' as a unit."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     id: "q5",
+                     question: "Which punctuation best emphasizes the parenthetical element? 'The winner ___ my best friend ___ jumped for joy.'",
+                     options: [
+                       "Commas: winner, my best friend, jumped",
+                       "Parentheses: winner (my best friend) jumped",
+                       "Dashes: winner‚Äîmy best friend‚Äîjumped",
+                       "No punctuation needed"
+                     ],
+                     correctAnswer: 2,
+                     explanation: "Dashes create the most emphasis. All three could work, but dashes highlight that your best friend won!"

+                       "It was a, bright sunny day.",
+                       "It was a bright sunny day."

+                     explanation: "Correct! Test: 'bright and sunny day' ‚úì | 'sunny, bright day' ‚úì. They're coordinate, so comma goes between them."

+             }
+           ]
+         },
+         {
+           id: "grammar-6",
+           title: "Chapter 6: Sentence Variety and Style",
+           lessons: [
+             {
+               id: "grammar-6-1",
+               title: "Simple, Compound, and Complex Sentences",
+               type: "lesson",
+               content: {
+                 introduction: "By 6th grade, the goal is to stop writing choppy sentences and start varying your style. Using different sentence patterns shows how ideas relate and makes writing more interesting.",
+                 explanation: "**Three Types of Sentences:**\n\n**1. Simple Sentence**\nOne independent clause (one complete thought):\n- **Structure**: Subject + Verb\n- Example: The dog barked.\n- Example: Maria and Tom played basketball after school. (still simple - one main action)\n\n**2. Compound Sentence**\nTwo or more independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction (FANBOYS: **F**or, **A**nd, **N**or, **B**ut, **O**r, **Y**et, **S**o):\n- **Structure**: Independent Clause **+ comma + FANBOYS +** Independent Clause\n- Example: The dog barked**, and** the cat ran away.\n- Example: I studied hard**, yet** I still felt nervous.\n\n**Key Rule**: Use a comma BEFORE the conjunction!\n\n**3. Complex Sentence**\nOne independent clause + one or more dependent clauses:\n- **Structure**: Independent Clause + Dependent Clause (or reversed)\n- Example: **Because** it was raining, we stayed inside. (dependent, independent)\n- Example: We stayed inside **because** it was raining. (independent, dependent)\n\n**Common Subordinating Conjunctions** (start dependent clauses):\n- Time: when, while, before, after, until, since\n- Cause: because, since, as\n- Condition: if, unless, whether\n- Contrast: although, though, even though, while\n\n**Punctuation Rule for Complex Sentences:**\n- If dependent clause comes FIRST ‚Üí use comma\n  - **When** I finish homework**, **I'll watch TV.\n- If independent clause comes FIRST ‚Üí usually no comma\n  - I'll watch TV **when** I finish homework.\n\n---\n\n**Why Vary Sentence Types?**\n\n1. **Avoid Choppy Writing:**\n   - Choppy: \"I woke up. I ate breakfast. I went to school. I saw my friend.\"\n   - Better: \"When I woke up, I ate breakfast before going to school, where I saw my friend.\"\n\n2. **Show Relationships Between Ideas:**\n   - Simple: States a fact\n   - Compound: Shows equal ideas or contrast\n   - Complex: Shows cause/effect, time, or condition\n\n3. **Create Rhythm:**\n   Mix short and long sentences for variety!\n\n**Example of Good Variety:**\n\"The storm began suddenly. (simple) Dark clouds rolled in, and lightning flashed across the sky. (compound) Although we were scared, we stayed calm and found shelter. (complex) We were safe. (simple)\"",
+                 examples: [
+                   {
+                     text: "Complex: Although the test was difficult, I did my best.",
+                     explanation: "Dependent clause 'Although the test was difficult' + comma + independent clause 'I did my best.'"
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "Compound: The book was long, but it was very interesting.",
+                     explanation: "Two independent clauses joined by comma + 'but' (FANBOYS)."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "Simple: The students completed the assignment.",
+                     explanation: "One independent clause with subject (students) and verb (completed)."
+                   }
+                 ]
+               }
+             },
+             {
+               id: "grammar-6-2",
+               title: "Practice: Sentence Variety",
+               type: "exercise",
+               content: {
+                 instructions: "Identify sentence types and choose correctly punctuated sentences.",
+                 questions: [
+                   {
+                     id: "q1",
+                     question: "What type of sentence is this? 'Because it was raining, we canceled the picnic.'",
+                     options: ["Simple", "Compound", "Complex", "Fragment"],
+                     correctAnswer: 2,
+                     explanation: "This is complex. It has a dependent clause 'Because it was raining' and an independent clause 'we canceled the picnic.'"
+                   },
+                   {
+                     id: "q2",
+                     question: "Which sentence is punctuated correctly?",
+                     options: [
+                       "I want to go swimming but, it's too cold.",
+                       "I want to go swimming, but it's too cold.",
+                       "I want to go swimming but it's too cold.",
+                       "I want to go, swimming but it's too cold."
+                     ],
+                     correctAnswer: 1,
+                     explanation: "Compound sentences need a comma BEFORE the coordinating conjunction (but)."
+                   },

+                     options: ["Simple", "Compound", "Complex", "Fragment"],
+                     correctAnswer: 1,
+                     explanation: "This is compound. Two independent clauses joined by comma + 'and.'"

+                       "When, the bell rings we will go to lunch.",
+                       "When the bell, rings we will go to lunch."

+                     correctAnswer: 1,

+                     options: ["Simple", "Compound", "Complex", "Run-on"],

+           ]
+         },
+         {
+           id: "grammar-7",
+           title: "Chapter 7: Avoiding Common Errors",
+           lessons: [
+             {
+               id: "grammar-7-1",
+               title: "Pronoun Shifts and Misplaced Modifiers",
+               type: "lesson",
+               content: {
+                 introduction: "Grade 6 is the year to clean up common errors. Two major pitfalls are pronoun shifts (switching person) and misplaced modifiers (descriptive phrases in the wrong place).",
+                 explanation: "**Problem 1: Pronoun Shifts**\n\nA pronoun shift occurs when you inconsistently change the person (I, you, one, he, they) you're using.\n\n**Types of Person:**\n- **First person**: I, we, me, us, my, our\n- **Second person**: you, your, yours\n- **Third person**: he, she, it, they, him, her, them, one\n\n**The Rule**: Be consistent! Don't switch persons in the middle of writing.\n\n**Example 1: I ‚Üí You Shift**\n- **Wrong**: \"When **I** study for a test, **you** should start several days early.\"\n  - Problem: Shifts from first person (I) to second person (you)\n- **Right**: \"When **I** study for a test, **I** start several days early.\"\n- **Also Right**: \"When **you** study for a test, **you** should start several days early.\"\n\n**Example 2: You ‚Üí One Shift**\n- **Wrong**: \"If **you** want to succeed, **one** must work hard.\"\n  - Problem: Shifts from second person (you) to third person (one)\n- **Right**: \"If **you** want to succeed, **you** must work hard.\"\n\n**Example 3: One ‚Üí They Shift**\n- **Wrong**: \"When **one** reads carefully, **they** understand better.\"\n  - Problem: Shifts from third singular (one) to third plural (they)\n- **Right**: \"When **one** reads carefully, **one** understands better.\"\n- **Better**: \"When **people** read carefully, **they** understand better.\"\n\n---\n\n**Problem 2: Misplaced Modifiers**\n\nA modifier is a word or phrase that describes something. It must be placed next to what it modifies!\n\n**The Rule**: Place modifiers as close as possible to what they describe.\n\n**Example 1:**\n- **Wrong**: \"I saw a dog **wearing a hat** walking down the street.\"\n  - Problem: Was the hat walking down the street?\n- **Right**: \"**While walking down the street**, I saw a dog wearing a hat.\"\n- **Also Right**: \"I saw a dog wearing a hat **while I was walking down the street**.\"\n\n**Example 2:**\n- **Wrong**: \"The teacher gave the test to the students **that was very difficult**.\"\n  - Problem: Were the students difficult?\n- **Right**: \"The teacher gave **the test that was very difficult** to the students.\"\n\n**Example 3:**\n- **Wrong**: \"We saw the mountain **driving down the highway**.\"\n  - Problem: Was the mountain driving?\n- **Right**: \"**While driving down the highway**, we saw the mountain.\"\n\n**Example 4:**\n- **Wrong**: \"She served sandwiches to the children **on paper plates**.\"\n  - Problem: Were the children on paper plates?\n- **Right**: \"She served sandwiches **on paper plates** to the children.\"\n\n**Tip to Avoid Misplaced Modifiers:**\nAsk yourself: \"What is this phrase describing?\" Then place it next to that word!",
+                 examples: [
+                   {
+                     text: "Wrong: 'When you read this book, one will learn a lot.' | Right: 'When you read this book, you will learn a lot.'",
+                     explanation: "Don't shift from 'you' (second person) to 'one' (third person). Stay consistent."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "Wrong: 'The car belongs to my neighbor with the red door.' | Right: 'The car with the red door belongs to my neighbor.'",
+                     explanation: "The phrase 'with the red door' should be next to 'car,' not 'neighbor,' unless the neighbor has a red door!"
+                   },
+                   {
+                     text: "Wrong: 'If one wants to improve, you must practice.' | Right: 'If one wants to improve, one must practice.' OR 'If you want to improve, you must practice.'",
+                     explanation: "Don't mix 'one' and 'you' - pick one and stick with it throughout."
+                   }
+                 ]
+               }
+             },
+             {
+               id: "grammar-7-2",
+               title: "Practice: Avoiding Common Errors",

+                 explanation: "**Paragraph Structure:**\n\n1. **Topic Sentence**: States the main idea\n   - Usually the first sentence\n   - Tells what the paragraph is about\n\n2. **Supporting Sentences**: Provide details, examples, or evidence\n   - 3-5 sentences that explain or prove the main idea\n   - Use specific examples and details\n\n3. **Concluding Sentence**: Wraps up the paragraph\n   - Restates the main idea in a new way\n   - Can transition to the next paragraph\n\n**Tips for strong paragraphs:**\n- Stay focused on one main idea\n- Use transition words (First, Next, Also, Finally)\n- Include specific examples\n- Make sure all sentences relate to the topic",

+           title: "Chapter 2: Narrative Writing",
+           lessons: [
+             {
+               id: "writing-2-1",
+               title: "Elements of Narrative Writing",
+               type: "lesson",
+               content: {
+                 introduction: "Narrative writing tells a story with characters, setting, plot, and a clear sequence of events.",
+                 explanation: "**Key Elements of Narrative Writing:**\n\n1. **Characters**: The people or animals in your story\n   - Protagonist: main character\n   - Describe their traits and feelings\n\n2. **Setting**: Where and when the story takes place\n   - Use sensory details (sight, sound, smell, touch, taste)\n\n3. **Plot**: The sequence of events\n   - Beginning: Introduce characters and setting\n   - Middle: Present a problem or conflict\n   - End: Resolve the problem\n\n4. **Point of View**: Who tells the story\n   - First person: I, we (narrator is in the story)\n   - Third person: He, she, they (narrator is outside)\n\n5. **Dialogue**: Conversations between characters\n   - Use quotation marks\n   - Shows character personality\n\n**Writing Tips:**\n- Show, don't just tell (use actions and dialogue)\n- Use transition words (First, Then, Next, Finally)\n- Include descriptive details\n- Build to a climax",

+                   {
+                     id: "q2",
+                     question: "What is the main conflict or problem?",
+                     options: [
+                       "Alex doesn't have a project",
+                       "The volcano doesn't work",
+                       "Alex is nervous about presenting to the judges",
+                       "Marcus is competing against Alex"
+                     ],
+                     correctAnswer: 2,
+                     explanation: "Alex is nervous about his presentation, as shown by him clutching his board nervously and taking a deep breath."
+                   },
+                   {
+                     id: "q3",
+                     question: "How is the conflict resolved?",
+                     options: [
+                       "Alex runs away",
+                       "Marcus helps present",
+                       "Alex successfully presents and wins a blue ribbon",
+                       "The judges don't come to his table"
+                     ],
+                     correctAnswer: 2,
+                     explanation: "Alex overcomes his nervousness, presents successfully, and receives a blue ribbon, resolving the conflict."
+                   }
+                 ]
+               }
+             }
+           ]
+         }
+       ]
+     }
+   ]
+ };
+ 
+ 
+ 
```

+ # California Grade 6 Grammar Module - Complete Update
+ 
+ ## ‚úÖ Successfully Integrated California Common Core Standards
+ 
+ ### Module Overview: **Grammar** (7 Chapters Total)
+ 
+ All content is now fully aligned with **California Common Core State Standards (CCSS) for Grade 6**, with the biggest focus on **pronoun mastery** and **sentence variety** ‚Äî the two most important grammar goals for 6th graders.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## üìö Complete Grammar Module Chapters
+ 
+ ### **Chapter 1: Parts of Speech** (Original - Maintained)
+ - Nouns, Pronouns, and Verbs
+ - Identifying parts of speech in context
+ - 3 practice questions
+ 
+ ### **Chapter 2: Sentence Structure** (Original - Maintained)
+ - Simple and Compound Sentences
+ - FANBOYS coordinating conjunctions
+ - Comma usage before conjunctions
+ - 3 practice questions
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## üåü NEW CHAPTERS - California Grade 6 Standards
+ 
+ ### **Chapter 3: Mastering Pronouns - Part 1** ‚≠ê NEW
+ **Focus: Pronoun Case (Most Important Grammar Goal for Grade 6!)**
+ 
+ **Content Covered:**
+ 1. **Subjective Case** (I, he, she, we, they)
+    - Used when pronoun is doing the action
+    
+ 2. **Objective Case** (me, him, her, us, them)
+    - Used when pronoun is receiving the action
+    - Always used after prepositions (to, for, with, between)
+ 
+ 3. **Possessive Case** (my, mine, his, her, hers, our, ours, their, theirs, its)
+    - Shows ownership
+ 
+ **Key Strategies Taught:**
+ - ‚úÖ **"Remove the other person" trick** for compound subjects/objects
+   - "John and I went" ‚Üí Remove "John and" ‚Üí "I went" ‚úì
+   - "Between you and me" ‚Üí Remove "you and" ‚Üí "Between me" ‚úì
+ - ‚úÖ Common trouble spots: Compound subjects, prepositions
+ - ‚úÖ After prepositions, ALWAYS use objective case
+ 
+ **Practice Questions: 6**
+ - Compound subjects (I vs. me)
+ - After prepositions (between you and I/me)
+ - Possessive pronouns (mine vs. my)
+ 
+ **California Standard**: L.6.1.a - Ensure pronouns are in proper case
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ### **Chapter 4: Mastering Pronouns - Part 2** ‚≠ê NEW
+ **Focus: Intensive Pronouns and Clear Antecedents**
+ 
+ **Content Covered:**
+ 
+ **1. Intensive Pronouns (Adding Emphasis)**
+ - Forms: myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves
+ - Purpose: Add emphasis to who did something
+ - Examples:
+   - "I did the homework **myself**." (emphasizes I did it personally)
+   - "The principal **herself** made the announcement."
+ 
+ **Common Mistakes:**
+ - ‚ùå "Myself and Tom went to the game." 
+ - ‚úì "Tom and I went to the game."
+ - Rule: DON'T use intensive pronouns as subjects!
+ 
+ **2. Clear Antecedents (Avoiding Vague Pronouns)**
+ - Every pronoun must clearly refer to ONE specific noun
+ - ‚ùå "Sarah and Jane went shopping, and **she** bought a dress." (Who is she?)
+ - ‚úì "Sarah and Jane went shopping, and **Sarah** bought a dress."
+ 
+ **Vague Pronoun Types:**
+ - Unclear "she/he/it"
+ - Vague "they" (In the article, they say...)
+ - Ambiguous "it"
+ 
+ **Rules Taught:**
+ 1. Make sure every pronoun clearly refers to ONE noun
+ 2. When in doubt, repeat the noun
+ 3. Place pronouns close to their antecedents
+ 4. Avoid using "they" without a clear antecedent
+ 
+ **Practice Questions: 5**
+ - Intensive pronoun usage
+ - Identifying vague pronouns
+ - Fixing unclear antecedents
+ 
+ **California Standard**: L.6.1 - Recognize and correct vague pronouns
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ### **Chapter 5: Punctuation for Clarity** ‚≠ê NEW
+ **Focus: Parenthetical Elements and Coordinate Adjectives**
+ 
+ **Content Covered:**
+ 
+ **1. Parenthetical Elements (Non-Essential Information)**
+ Set off extra information with commas, parentheses, or dashes:
+ 
+ **A. Commas** (most common):
+ - The principal**, Mr. Smith,** gave a speech.
+ - My teacher**, who has taught for 20 years,** is experienced.
+ 
+ **B. Parentheses** (very extra info):
+ - The test **(which covers chapters 1-5)** is on Friday.
+ 
+ **C. Dashes** (emphasis):
+ - The winner**‚Äîmy best friend‚Äî**was announced.
+ 
+ **Test**: Remove the parenthetical element - does the sentence still work? If yes, it's non-essential!
+ 
+ **2. Coordinate Adjectives**
+ Adjectives that equally describe the same noun need commas.
+ 
+ **The Two Tests:**
+ 1. Can you put "and" between them?
+ 2. Can you reverse the order?
+ 
+ If YES to both ‚Üí Use comma!
+ 
+ **Examples:**
+ - ‚úì It was a long**, **exhausting day. (long and exhausting ‚úì | exhausting, long ‚úì)
+ - ‚úó She bought a small red car. (small and red car? awkward - NO comma)
+ 
+ **Practice Questions: 6**
+ - Punctuating appositives
+ - Comma usage with non-essential clauses
+ - Identifying coordinate adjectives
+ - Choosing commas, parentheses, or dashes
+ 
+ **California Standard**: L.6.2.a - Use punctuation (commas, parentheses, dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ### **Chapter 6: Sentence Variety and Style** ‚≠ê NEW
+ **Focus: Simple, Compound, and Complex Sentences**
+ 
+ **Content Covered:**
+ 
+ **1. Simple Sentence**
+ - One independent clause
+ - Example: The dog barked.
+ 
+ **2. Compound Sentence**
+ - Two independent clauses joined by FANBOYS + comma
+ - Structure: Independent, **FANBOYS** Independent
+ - Example: I studied hard**, yet** I felt nervous.
+ - **Key Rule**: Comma BEFORE the conjunction!
+ 
+ **3. Complex Sentence**
+ - Independent clause + dependent clause
+ - Dependent clause starts with subordinating conjunction
+ 
+ **Subordinating Conjunctions:**
+ - Time: when, while, before, after, until, since
+ - Cause: because, since, as
+ - Condition: if, unless, whether
+ - Contrast: although, though, even though, while
+ 
+ **Punctuation Rules:**
+ - Dependent clause FIRST ‚Üí use comma
+   - **When** I finish homework**, **I'll watch TV.
+ - Independent clause FIRST ‚Üí usually no comma
+   - I'll watch TV **when** I finish homework.
+ 
+ **Why Vary Sentences?**
+ 1. Avoid choppy writing
+ 2. Show relationships between ideas
+ 3. Create rhythm and interest
+ 
+ **Practice Questions: 6**
+ - Identifying sentence types
+ - Correct punctuation for compound sentences
+ - Correct punctuation for complex sentences
+ - Creating sentence variety
+ 
+ **California Standard**: L.6.3.a - Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader interest, and style
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ### **Chapter 7: Avoiding Common Errors** ‚≠ê NEW
+ **Focus: Pronoun Shifts and Misplaced Modifiers**
+ 
+ **Content Covered:**
+ 
+ **1. Pronoun Shifts (Consistency Errors)**
+ 
+ **Types of Person:**
+ - First: I, we, me, us (the speaker)
+ - Second: you, your (the person spoken to)
+ - Third: he, she, it, they, one (person/thing spoken about)
+ 
+ **The Rule**: DON'T SWITCH PERSONS!
+ 
+ **Common Errors:**
+ - ‚ùå "When **I** study, **you** should start early." (I ‚Üí you shift)
+ - ‚úì "When **I** study, **I** start early."
+ 
+ - ‚ùå "If **you** want to succeed, **one** must work hard." (you ‚Üí one shift)
+ - ‚úì "If **you** want to succeed, **you** must work hard."
+ 
+ **2. Misplaced Modifiers**
+ 
+ **The Rule**: Place descriptive phrases next to what they describe!
+ 
+ **Common Errors:**
+ - ‚ùå "I saw a dog **wearing a hat** walking down the street." (Was the hat walking?)
+ - ‚úì "**While walking down the street**, I saw a dog wearing a hat."
+ 
+ - ‚ùå "We saw the mountain **driving down the highway**." (Was the mountain driving?)
+ - ‚úì "**While driving down the highway**, we saw the mountain."
+ 
+ - ‚ùå "She served sandwiches to the children **on paper plates**." (Were children on plates?)
+ - ‚úì "She served sandwiches **on paper plates** to the children."
+ 
+ **Strategy**: Ask "What is this phrase describing?" Then place it next to that word!
+ 
+ **Practice Questions: 6**
+ - Identifying pronoun shifts
+ - Correcting pronoun consistency
+ - Fixing misplaced modifiers
+ - Identifying correctly placed modifiers
+ 
+ **California Standard**: L.6.1 - Demonstrate command of conventions of standard English
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## üìä Complete Grammar Module Statistics
+ 
+ | Metric | Count |
+ |--------|-------|
+ | **Total Chapters** | 7 (was 2, now 7) |
+ | **Total Lessons** | 14 (7 instruction + 7 exercises) |
+ | **Total Practice Questions** | 38 |
+ | **Pronoun Chapters** | 2 full chapters (Chapters 3 &amp; 4) |
+ | **Punctuation Rules** | 5+ major rules |

+ | **Common Errors Addressed** | 2 major types |
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## üéØ California Common Core Alignment Summary
+ 
+ ### Standards Directly Addressed:
+ 
+ **L.6.1** - Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar
+ - ‚úÖ **L.6.1.a** - Ensure pronouns are in the proper case (subjective, objective, possessive) ‚≠ê
+ - ‚úÖ **L.6.1.b** - Use intensive pronouns (myself, ourselves, etc.) ‚≠ê
+ - ‚úÖ **L.6.1.c** - Recognize and correct vague pronouns ‚≠ê
+ - ‚úÖ **L.6.1.d** - Recognize variations from standard English
+ - ‚úÖ Pronoun shifts and consistency
+ 
+ **L.6.2** - Demonstrate command of conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling
+ - ‚úÖ **L.6.2.a** - Use punctuation (commas, parentheses, dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements ‚≠ê
+ - ‚úÖ Coordinate adjectives punctuation
+ 
+ **L.6.3** - Use knowledge of language and its conventions
+ - ‚úÖ **L.6.3.a** - Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style ‚≠ê
+ - ‚úÖ Maintain consistency in style and tone
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## üåü Key California-Specific Features
+ 
+ ### 1. **Pronoun Mastery - TOP PRIORITY ‚≠ê**
+ **Two Full Chapters** dedicated to pronouns (Chapters 3 &amp; 4):
+ - Proper case (subjective, objective, possessive)
+ - Intensive pronouns for emphasis
+ - Clear antecedents (avoiding vague pronouns)
+ - Common mistakes and strategies
+ 
+ **Why This Matters:**
+ "Mastery of pronouns is arguably the most important grammar goal for 6th graders" - directly from CA standards
+ 
+ ### 2. **Practical Strategies Students Can Use**
+ - ‚úÖ **"Remove the other person" trick** for choosing I vs. me
+ - ‚úÖ **Two-test method** for coordinate adjectives (and test + reverse test)
+ - ‚úÖ **"Can you remove it?" test** for parenthetical elements
+ - ‚úÖ **"What does it describe?"** strategy for avoiding misplaced modifiers
+ 
+ ### 3. **Sentence Variety for Sophisticated Writing**
+ Stop writing "choppy" sentences:
+ - Mix simple, compound, and complex sentences
+ - Show relationships between ideas
+ - Create rhythm and interest
+ - Use subordinating conjunctions effectively
+ 
+ ### 4. **Common Pitfalls Addressed**
+ Real errors 6th graders make:
+ - "Between you and I" ‚Üí should be "me"
+ - "Myself and Tom went" ‚Üí should be "Tom and I"
+ - Pronoun shifts (I ‚Üí you ‚Üí one)
+ - Misplaced modifiers ("dog wearing a hat walking")
+ 
+ ### 5. **Punctuation for Clarity**
+ Sophisticated punctuation techniques:
+ - Three ways to set off parenthetical info (commas, parentheses, dashes)
+ - When and how to use each
+ - Coordinate adjectives
+ - Complex sentence punctuation
+ 
+ ---

+ ## üì± Student Learning Outcomes

+ 
+ ‚úÖ Choose the correct pronoun case (I vs. me) in ANY situation
+ ‚úÖ Use intensive pronouns correctly for emphasis
+ ‚úÖ Avoid vague pronoun references
+ ‚úÖ Punctuate parenthetical elements with commas, parentheses, or dashes
+ ‚úÖ Identify and punctuate coordinate adjectives
+ ‚úÖ Write simple, compound, and complex sentences
+ ‚úÖ Vary sentence patterns for better writing
+ ‚úÖ Avoid pronoun shifts
+ ‚úÖ Correct misplaced modifiers

### **Chapter 3: Mastering Pronouns - Part 1** ‚≠ê
**THE MOST IMPORTANT GRAMMAR GOAL FOR GRADE 6!**

**Content:**
- ‚úÖ **Subjective Case**: I, he, she, we, they (doing the action)
- ‚úÖ **Objective Case**: me, him, her, us, them (receiving the action)
- ‚úÖ **Possessive Case**: my, mine, his, hers, ours, theirs

**Key Strategy Taught:**
- **"Remove the other person" trick**
  - "John and I went" ‚Üí Remove "John and" ‚Üí "I went" ‚úì
  - "Between you and me" ‚Üí Remove "you and" ‚Üí "Between me" ‚úì

**Common Errors Fixed:**
- ‚ùå "Me and John went" ‚Üí ‚úì "John and I went"
- ‚ùå "Between you and I" ‚Üí ‚úì "Between you and me"
- ‚ùå "The teacher picked John and I" ‚Üí ‚úì "The teacher picked John and me"

### **Chapter 4: Mastering Pronouns - Part 2** ‚≠ê
**Focus: Intensive Pronouns & Clear Antecedents**

**Intensive Pronouns:**
- myself, yourself, himself, herself, ourselves, themselves
- "I did the homework **myself**." (adds emphasis)
- ‚ùå "Myself and Tom went" (WRONG - don't use as subject!)

**Vague Antecedents:**
- ‚ùå "Sarah and Jane went shopping, and **she** bought a dress." (Who?)
- ‚úì "Sarah and Jane went shopping, and **Sarah** bought a dress."

**5 Practice Questions**

---

### **Chapter 5: Punctuation for Clarity** ‚≠ê
**Focus: Parenthetical Elements & Coordinate Adjectives**

**Parenthetical Elements** (3 ways):
1. **Commas**: The principal**, Mr. Smith,** gave a speech.
2. **Parentheses**: The test **(chapters 1-5)** is Friday.
3. **Dashes**: The winner**‚Äîmy best friend‚Äî**was announced.

**Coordinate Adjectives:**
- Two tests: Can you add "and"? Can you reverse them?
- ‚úì "A long**, **exhausting day" (long and exhausting ‚úì)
- ‚úó "A small red car" (small and red car? awkward - NO comma)

**6 Practice Questions**

---

### **Chapter 6: Sentence Variety and Style** ‚≠ê
**Stop writing "choppy" sentences!**

**Three Sentence Types:**

**1. Simple**: One independent clause
- The dog barked.

**2. Compound**: Two independent clauses + FANBOYS
- I studied hard**, yet** I felt nervous.
- **Rule**: Comma BEFORE conjunction!

**3. Complex**: Independent + dependent clause
- **Because** it was raining**, **we stayed inside.
- **Rule**: Comma after dependent clause when it comes first!

**Subordinating Conjunctions:**
- Time: when, while, before, after
- Cause: because, since, as
- Condition: if, unless, whether
- Contrast: although, though

**6 Practice Questions**

---

### **Chapter 7: Avoiding Common Errors** ‚≠ê
**Clean up Grade 6 common mistakes!**

**Problem 1: Pronoun Shifts**
Don't switch persons (I ‚Üí you ‚Üí one):
- ‚ùå "When **I** study, **you** should start early."
- ‚úì "When **I** study, **I** should start early."

**Problem 2: Misplaced Modifiers**
Place descriptions next to what they describe:
- ‚ùå "I saw a dog **wearing a hat** walking down the street." (Was the hat walking?)
- ‚úì "**While walking down the street**, I saw a dog wearing a hat."

**6 Practice Questions**
